Fig. 1 ORTEP view (40 % thermal ellipsoid probability) of complex (a) CuPhenAc (b) CuPhenCl, (c) CuPhenIm, (d) CuPhenMAc. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Graph showing the % conversion and % selectivity with respect to variation of a) solvent, b) amount of oxidant, c) catalyst amount, the values in the parenthesis are Cu content, d) reaction time. The solvent, oxidant and catalyst amount optimized parameters were estimated by performing the reaction for 1 h with CuPhenAc. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Graph showing % conversion and % selectivity with respect to the variation of a) temperature, b) solvent, c) H2O2 amount, d) catalyst amount, Cu content are given in the parenthesis, (red for CuPhenIm, black for CuPhenMAc) of CuPhenMAc (solid line) and CuPhenIm (dotted line) for BA oxidation. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Graph shows the optimization of a) solvent, b) H2O2 amount c) catalyst amount, the values in the parenthesis represents the Cu content, d) reaction time in BA oxidation reaction with CuO nanocatalyst. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Graphs showing the optimization of a) solvent b) oxidant amount, c) time, d) catalyst amount, the values in the parenthesis are Cu content (black for CuPhenIm, red for CuPhenMAc) with CuPhenMAc (black line) and CuPhenIm (red line) complexes. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 (a) Rate vs substrate concentration of catechol, (b) Lineweaver-Burk plot of 1/substrate concentration vs 1/Rate (blue line for CuPhenMAc and red line for CuPhenIm). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 a) UV–vis spectrum of the CuPhenCl recorded in CH3CN and showing the growth of the peak at 440 nm with the increasing amount of CH3CN, b) calculated absorption spectra using TD-DFT, c) frontier orbital’s involve in the electronic transition d) FTIR spectra recorded before (black line) and after the addition of H2O2 (red line), e) the corresponding Raman spectra, f) theoretically calculated FTIR of [Cu (OOH)(Phen)2]+. The IR and Raman spectra were recorded by treating CuPhenCl with H2O2 at 0–5 °C. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 CV plot of a) CuPhenCl, b) CuPhenAc in different solvents, c) CuPhenCl + H2O2 (black), CuPhenCl + H2O2 + BA (red), d) CuPhenAc + H2O2 (black), CuPhenAc + H2O2 + BA (red), e) shows the change in HOMO-LUMO orbital energy gap on changing the co-ordination sphere around Cu centre. All the CV was recorded using TBAP (tetrabutylammonium phosphate) as a supporting electrolyte at a scan rate of 50 mVs−1. Fig. 8 Scheme 1 Schematic representation of the different synthesis pathway of four Cu(II) complexes. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Plausible mechanism for the BA oxidation by CuPhenCl complex. Cu(II) catalysts both in homogeneous and heterogeneous form were synthesized to bring the distinction between the single and multiple site catalysis. The single site mononuclear complexes with axial occupancy of Cl- and CH3COO- ligand and the acetate, imidazolate bridged dinuclear Cu(II) complexes were tested for selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol and catechol oxidation. The reactivity of the complexes was compared with the multiple site copper oxide (CuO) nanocatalyst derived from the metal complex precursor. The single site Cu(II) catalyst showed much superior activity in the selective oxidation of BA compared to the dinuclear and the CuO-nanocatalyst. The oxidation of catechol to o-benzoquinone was however found to be catalyzed more preferably by the di-nuclear systems. The high lability of Cl- and -OOCH3 groups in the mononuclear complexes allowed the incoming oxidant, substrate as well as the solvent (acetonitrile, CH3CN) molecules to interact with the active Cu-centre and thereby favoured the benzyl alcohol oxidation. Both the experimental and theoretical studies provided a conclusive idea about the reaction mechanism of benzyl alcohol and catechol oxidation. UV–vis, cyclic voltammetric study and density functional theory (DFT) calculations provided the strong evidence for the formation of Cu-CH3CN complex during benzyl alcohol oxidation. FTIR and Raman study substantiated by the theoretical calculations indicated for the formation of Cu- hydroperoxo species during the catalytic studies. The kinetics study revealed for the 1st order kinetic for the catechol oxidation and the DFT study predicted for the exothermic nature of the catechol oxidation process. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Cu(II) complex CuO-nanocatalyst Benzyl alcohol Catechol Oxidation Reaction mechanism Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Copper is known to be one of the trace elements in the biological system [1]. A good number of metalloenzymes like plastocyanin, hemocyanin involving copper as active centre are known to catalyse different enzymatic reactions [2]. Intrigued by the bioactive copper systems, different copper complexes are synthesized to mimic the bio-system [3,4]. The concept of single site catalyst is also derived from the naturally occurring catalytic reaction involving metalloenzymes [5]. The single site catalysts are known to provide good selectivity for which the catalytic reactions taking place in our biological process are highly selective [6]. In this respect the Cu (II) Phenanthroline complexes (Cu-Phen) and such Cu-nitrogen co-ordinated complexes are well studied for DNA interaction and for anti-cancer activity [3,7–9]. However, the Cu-Phen complexes in mono, binuclear form are not well explored for benzyl alcohol (BA) oxidation reaction [10]. The oxidation of BA is one of the important reactions that is known to catalyse by different metal catalysts [11–13]. Due to the involvement of challenges and difficulties such as over oxidation, free radical mechanism, the BA oxidation reaction still remains as a reaction of research interest [14–16]. So far different Cu-based metal catalysts either in homogeneous or heterogeneous form have been studied for the BA oxidation [17–20]. For example, Das et al. performed such reaction with Cu phenanthroline complex using molecular oxygen and TEMPO as a promoter [21]. Recently, Zand et al. developed a new approach of BA oxidation via Cu-acetonitrile coordinated phenanthroline complex [22]. Ranjan et al. introduced mannich base ligand to form complex with Cu to do photocatalytic oxidation of such alcohol under visible light [23]. Paine et al. and co-worker designed various phenanthroline ligand-based copper complexes for alcohol oxidation [24]. Similar, to the BA oxidation, the catechol oxidation reaction by Cu- complex is well explored as they can mimic the catechol oxidase [25,26]. Recent studies have found that both the homogeneous and heterogeneous form of Cu catalyst shows the catechol oxidase activity by doing the oxidation of catechol to quinone [27–29]. The catechol oxidase, a Cu(II) metalloenzyme that contains a dicopper pair with each copper centre coordinated by three histidine residues and shuttles their oxidation sate between +2 and +1 is well known for such catalytic oxidation reaction [30,31]. A good number of dinuclear copper (II) complexes that can mimic the structural and functional aspects of catechol oxidase are well studied [32–35]. Vittal et al. reported penta-coordinated bis(μ-phenoxo)-bridged dicopper(II) complexes with reduced Schiff base ligands exhibiting diverse catecholase reactivity [36]. Recently, Mukherjee et al. synthesized bis(m-phenoxo)-bridged dicopper(II) complex that can promote catechol oxidation [37]. However, to the best of our knowledge a comparative study involving single site and multinuclear site for such catalytic oxidation reactions are not attempted. Therefore, to have a better understanding about the site preferential activity of alcohol oxidation reaction, herein we report for the synthesis of mono-nuclear, dinuclear and multicentred Cu- catalyst and their reactivity towards BA oxidation and catechol oxidation was compared. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Material Copper nitrate dihydrate (Cu(NO3)2.2H2O and sodium acetate trihydrate (CH3COONa .3H2O) were purchased from HiMedia, Pvt. Ltd. HPLC grade methanol and all solvent used were received from E-Merk. Benzyl alcohol (BA) was procured from Merck. Phenanthroline and Imidazole were received from Sigma-Aldrich. 30 % of H2O2 (hydrogen peroxide) and catechol was purchased from SRL. 2.2 Synthesis of acetato diphenanthroline copper (II) complex, CuPhenAc 5 mmol (2.41 g) of Cu(NO3)2.2H2O and 5 mmol (1.36 g) of CH3CO2Na.3H2O were dissolved separately in methanol. After that the CH3CO2Na .3H2O solution was added to the Cu(NO3)2.2H2O solution and stirred under refluxing condition for 2 h. To the mixture, 10 mmol (1.80 g) of phenanthroline (Phen) was added and stirred the solution for 48 h. The clear blue colour solution was then kept for crystallization and finally dark blue colour crystals of CuPhenAc was obtained after seven days of slow evaporation of the solvent, ( Scheme 1a). 2.3 Synthesis of chlorido diphenanthroline copper (II) complex, CuPhenCl For the synthesis of CuPhenCl, 1 g of the CuPhenAc complex was dissolved in a round bottom flask containing 10 mL of CH3OH solution and the solution was stirred for several minute with the drop wise addition of 2 mL HCl (hydrochloric acid, 0.001 M). Thereafter, the reaction mixture was vigorously stirred for 24 h. After that resultant mixture was kept for almost one month for slow evaporation of solvent to get dark green colour crystals of the complex, (Scheme 1b). 2.4 Synthesis of diacetate dimethoxytetraphenanthroline dicopper(II) complex, CuPhenMAc The CuPhenMAc was synthesized by dissolving 10 mmol (2.41 g) of Cu(NO3)2.2H2O and 10 mmol (1.36 g) of CH3CO2Na .3H2O in methanol and by stirring under refluxing condition for two hours. After two hours a 10 mmol (1.80 g) of phenanthroline (Phen) was added to the stirred solution and again refluxed it for 48 h. After the slow evaporation of the solution, the resultant blue crystals of the complex were obtained after eighteen days of crystallization period, (Scheme 1d). 2.5 Synthesis of Imidazolate diphenanthroline dicopper (II) complex, CuPhenIm For the preparation of CuPhenIm, 8 mmol (1.44 g) of phenanthroline and 2 mmol (0.136 g) of imidazole was dissolve in a 5 mL methanol. Cu(NO3)22 H2O solution (2 mmol, 0.45 g) was then added drop wise to the above solution. After that the reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24 h and then refluxed the solution again for 24 h. The final clear blue solution was kept for several weeks to get the crystals of the complex, (Scheme 1c). 2.6 Synthesis of CuO nanocatalyst CuO-nanocatalyst was prepared by calcinations of 2 g of CuPhenIm complex in a muffle furnace chamber at 350 °C in air. 2.7 General procedure for oxidation of benzyl alcohol by Cu(II) catalyst To perform the oxidation of BA, in a round bottom flask, 1 mmol of BA was added to required amount of H2O2 and 5 mg of the CuPhenCl. The reaction was performed in 5 mL of solvent acetonitrile (CH3CN) at room temperature. The progress of the reaction was monitored through TLC using ethyl acetate/ n-hexane, 1:9. The formation of benzaldehyde was confirmed by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) analysis after the isolation of desired product via column chromatography. The % conversion and % selectivity of the benzaldehyde product was measured by using Gas Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry (GC-MS) analysis. The results are calculated in mol. % by the following equation: % conversion= [moles of reactant reacted× 100/Initial moles of BA] and % selectivity= [moles of benzaldehyde× 100/moles of BA reacted]. 2.8 General procedure for oxidation of catechol by Cu(II) catalyst The catechol oxidation reaction was performed at room temperature in a round bottom flask using 1 mmol of catechol, 60 µL of H2O2 and 3 mg of the prepared catalyst using 5 mL of methanol (CH3OH). The entire reaction mixture was stirred for 1 h. The progress of the reaction was monitored via UV–vis spectroscopy. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of copper phenanthroline complexes The synthesized metal complexes were first characterised by Single crystal X-ray diffraction and are discussed below. 3.1.1 X-ray crystallographic structural analysis of the copper complexes The structure of complex CuPhenAc was established by single crystal X-ray analysis having composition [Cu(Phen)2(CH3COO)].2H2O.NO3 and it was crystallized in triclinic P-1 space group. The asymmetric unit of CuPhenAc contained one Cu(II) ion, two coordinated Phen ligands, one coordinated acetate ligand. Moreover, one nitric acid and two water molecules of crystallization were present in the lattice in its asymmetric unit, Fig. 1a. Each Cu(II) center had a distorted octahedral geometry around it and this geometry was satisfied by two oxygen atoms from one acetate ligand and four N atoms from two Phen ligands. The acetate ions were bonded to copper center through η2-chelating mode having unequal bond length Cu1-O1 = 2.134 Å and Cu1-O2 = 2.439 Å. Similarly, all four Cu-N bonds were observed to be unequal; Cu1-N1 = 2.096 Å, Cu1-N2 = 2.009 Å, Cu1-N3 = 2.022 Å and Cu1-N4 = 2.174 Å. Selected metal-ligand bond parameters are listed in SI, Table S1. Self-assembled cyclic tetrameric water cluster was observed in the solid state structure and was stabilized by Cu(II) phenanthroline complex. Each cyclic tetrameric water cluster was connected through H-bonding to two nitrate anions and two metal coordination units as shown in Fig. S1a. In solid state, nitrate ion, metal coordination and the cyclic water cluster all were interconnected with different supramolecular interactions such as O-H…O, C-H…O and C-H…π interactions and all these interactions stabilized the molecule, Fig. S1b. The complex, [Cu(Phen)2Cl)]H2O.NO3. (CuPhenCl) crystallized in triclinic, P-1 space group and the asymmetric unit was constituted by two coordinated Phen ligands, one coordinated chloride ligand, and one lattice nitrate and one lattice water molecule. The ORTEP diagram of CuPhenCl is shown in Fig. 1b. Copper (II) ion in CuPhenCl was in an Cl1N4 environment with distorted trigonal bipyramidal coordination geometry. N atoms from each Phen ligand coordinated to Cu ion with equal bond distances of Cu1-N1 = 1.996 and Cu-N3 = 1.993 Å were axially located trans to each other, Fig. S2a. The two N and one Cl atoms were coordinated to Cu(II) ion having bond distances of Cu1-N2 = 2.133, Cu1-N4 = 2.098 and Cu1-Cl1 = 2.295 Å and were located at the equatorial position of trigonal bipyramidal geometry. The distortion in the complex was realized by observing the bond angles such as ∠Cl1-Cu1-N1 = 91.61°, ∠N3-Cu1-Cl1 = 92.60°, ∠N2-Cu1-Cl1 = 119.43°, ∠N4-Cu1-N2 = 104.89° and ∠N4-Cu1-Cl1 = 135.67° and these bond angles deviated from ideal trigonal bipyramidal geometry. Selected metal-ligand bond parameters are listed in Table S1. Lattice water molecule and nitrate ions were connected with O-H…O hydrogen bonding and these two species were further linked with the complex molecule in the solid state with different non-covalent interactions such as C-H…O, O-H…π, O-H…Cl interactions, Fig. S2b. Besides these, C-H…π interaction among complex molecules helped in bringing molecules closer to each other in the solid state. All these interactions lead to the generation of 3D supramolecular network of CuPhenCl, Fig. S2c . The single crystal X-ray analysis of complex CuPhenIm, [Cu2(Phen)4(Imidazole)].4H2O.3NO3 revealed that the CuPhenIm crystallized in triclinic P-1 space group. The asymmetric unit of CuPhenIm contained two Cu(II) ion. Each Cu(II) center was bonded with two phenanthroline molecules and one deprotonated imidazole ligand that served as a bridge between the two copper centers is shown in Fig. 1c. Moreover, the four lattice water molecules and three nitrate ions were present outside the coordination sphere, Fig. S3a. Distorted square pyramidal geometry around each Cu(II) ion was governed by four donor N atoms from two phenanthroline molecules and fifth coordination site are occupied by imidazole N atom, Fig. 3b. The distortion was observed from the deviation in bond angles such as ∠N1-Cu1-N5 = 93.77(9)º, ∠N1-Cu1-N2 = 81.06(9)º, ∠N2-Cu1-N3 = 91.97(9)º and ∠N3-Cu1-N5 = 93.34(9)º. Selected M-L bond parameters are listed in SI, Table S1. The complex stabilized in the solid state by hydrogen bonding such as O-H…O, C-H…O, C-H…π and π…π stacking interactions as shown in Fig. S3c and these intermolecular interaction leads to the formation of layered 3D supramolecular structure. The lattice water molecules formed a 1D hexameric water cluster (exhibiting R6 6(12) cyclic H-bonds) bridged by nitrate-water tetramer exhibiting R4 2(8) cyclic H-bond, Fig. S3d. The CuPhenMAc, [Cu2(Phen)2(CH3COO)2(CH3O)2].2HNO3.2H2O crystallized as a dinuclear complex having two Cu(II) centers with a Cu…Cu distance of 3.045 Å. The crystallographically independent unit contained one Cu(II) ion, one neutral Phen ligand, one acetate ion, one mono ionic methanolate ion, one nitric acid and a water molecule, Fig. 1d. Each Cu(II) center exhibited a distorted square pyramidal geometry with two O and two N basal atoms were coplanar, while the methanolate O atom were positioned perpendicular to this plane, Fig. S4a. Both the acetate ions were coordinated through bridging bidentate (µ2- η1:η1) mode with an identical bond distance of 1.931 (Cu1-O3) and 1.954 Å (Cu1-O2). The two bond distances between the copper center and Phen ligand as Cu-N1 and Cu-N2 were almost identical and measured as 2.006 and 2.034 Å. Selected metal-ligand bond parameters are listed in SI, Table S1. The solid-state structure represented a nitric acid-water tetrameric cluster having R2 2(4) cyclic hydrogen bonds and the nitric acids were further linked to methanolate O through unusual O…O contact [38]. The complex was further stabilized by supramolecular contact such as C-H…O and helped in the formation of 3D layer structure, Fig. S4b. ( Table 1). The cyclic voltammetric study was also performed for all the synthesized metal complexes and cyclic voltammogram (CV) plots are shown in Fig. S6. In CuPhenAc, a redox couple was observed between −0.12 and 0.01 V. Similarly in CuPhenCl an anodic peak at +0.2 V and reduction peak at +0.1 V was observed, Fig. S6a,b. The CVs were found to resemble with those reported by Leandri et al. for similar type of Cu(II) complexes [39]. The dinuclear complex of CuPhenIm exhibited anodic peak at (Epa) at +1.2 V for Cu(III/II) redox couple, Fig. S6c [40]. The peak at +0.93 V was attributed to the oxidation of Cu(II) to Cu(III) and the cathodic peak (Epc) at −0.59 V was for the reduction of Cu(II) to Cu(I) [41]. The peak at −0.93 V was probably for the Phen ligand as the peak was similar to that recorded only for the Phen ligand (provided in SI, Fig. S5). Similarly, in CuPhenMAc complex, Epa at −0.58 correspond to the anodic peak of Phen and the other at −0.90 V may due to Cu(II/I) redox couple, Fig. S6d. The other cathodic signals (Epc) observed at −1.47 V, −1.25 V and −1.04 V were due to the reduction of Cu(I) to Cu(0) [42]. The synthesized complexes were also characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), TGA (Thermogravimetric analysis) and UV–vis analysis and the details are provided in SI (Supporting Information). In the complex, CuPhenAc the characteristics stretching band for νN C and νC C at 1558.7 cm−1, 1385.7 cm−1 clearly indicated the co-ordination of Phen ligand with Cu-metal, Fig. S7a [43]. The vibrational frequencies for asymmetric and symmetric vibration of acetate ligand (CH3COO-) appearing at 1521 cm−1, 1427 cm−1 with Δ(νa-νs) = 94 cm−1 in the complex also indicated for the co-ordination of CH3COO- in bidentate mode [44]. Similarly, in the other three complexes observed stretching frequency in between 1560 and 1580 cm−1 for νN C confirmed the co-ordination of Phen ligand. The FTIR spectrum of the complexes and their analysis are provided in SI, Fig. S6. The four complexes were characterized by TGA analysis to see the thermal stability and the details are provided in SI, Fig. S8 and Table S3. The four metal complexes represented almost a similar UV–vis spectrum, Fig. S9. The UV–vis spectrum showed intense band at 224, 269 nm for the π→π * bands [40,45], at 297 nm is due to the n→π * transition and this transition originated from the Phen ligand, Fig. S9 [46]. 3.2 Characterization of CuO-Nanocatalyst The CuO-material derived by calcination of CuPhenIm complex in air was characterized by powder X-Ray Diffraction (XRD), Scanning electron microscope (SEM), Transmission electron microscopes (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Raman analysis. The XRD pattern confirmed the formation of copper nanoparticles (CuO-NPs) with the observed 2θ (in degree) values at 32.40°, 35.46°, 38.66°, 48.75°, 53.39°, 58.22°, 61.45°, 66.2°, 68.01° [47,48]. The XRD pattern of Cu nanocatalyst is depicted in Fig. S10a, (black). The formation of CuO was confirmed by comparing the XRD pattern with the standard literature data (JCPDS card No. 80-1916) (Fig. S10a, blue) and also with freshly prepared CuO material by reported procedure, (Fig. S10a, red) [49]. SEM images indicated for a layered like morphology of the CuO material, Fig. S10b-c. From the energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis, Cu content was found to be 48.78 %, and O, C, N was found to be 31.04 %, 12.66 %, 7.52 % respectively, Fig. S10d. The presence of CuO-NPs in the CuO material was detected from the TEM (Transmission electron microscope). TEM analysis revealed the presence of fine CuO-NPs (Fig. S11a-b) having the dimension in the range of 10–20 nm as calculated from the particle size distribution analysis, Fig. S11c. The TEM images of the CuO prepared by literature report also resembled with those obtained from the CuPhenIm complex. The results thus suggested that the prepared Cu(II) complex can be easily used as precursor material for synthesis of highly crystalline CuO-nanomaterial. X-ray photo-electron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis, predicted the presence of Cu(II) state with Cu(2p3/2) peaks at 933.2 eV and Cu(2p1/2) at 952.9 eV, Fig. S12a [50,51]. The Cu(2p) XPS represented a well-defined satellite peaks for Cu(II) appearing at 941 eV and 943.5 eV. In O 1 s spectrum, the peak at 529.6 eV confirmed the presence of metal oxide (M-O) species and that at 531.2 eV was for O2- species [52], Fig. S12b. The N 1 s XPS showed the presence of NO3 - as impurities in CuO nanocatalyst with a characteristic peak at 406.9 eV, Fig. S12c [53]. The C 1 s peak having binding energy of 284.6 eV was used to fit all the XPS spectra, Fig. 12d. In the Raman spectra, the characteristic signals for CuO was observed at ~277.3 cm−1 and ~615.6 cm−1 confirming the formation of CuO nanomaterial from the copper complex, Fig. S13 [54,55]. In the cyclic voltammogram a sharp anodic peak (Epa) at +0.38 V for Cu(II/I) couple was observed, Fig. S14a. In the FTIR spectrum the peak at ~536 cm−1 was for Cu-O bond vibration while the sharp peak at ~1384.2 cm−1 was for NO3 - ion present as impurity in the material, Fig. S14b [56]. In the temperature programmed reduction (TPR) profile shown Fig S15) a signal at 330 °C indicated the reduction of CuO to Cu(0) [57]. The good surface coverage of the TPR profile implied for the presence of multiple Cu(II) site in the material. 4 Catalytic study The catalytic activity of the synthesized copper complexes and copper nanomaterial were tested for BA oxidation and catechol oxidation and they are discussed separately in different sections. 4.1 Benzyl alcohol oxidation by mononuclear copper (II) complexes To perform the BA oxidation reaction, at first the reaction was tested with the synthesized mononuclear complexes CuPhenAc and CuPhenCl. The reaction was initially performed taking 2 mg (0.0007 M) of CuPhenAc catalyst as a test catalyst using 50 µL of H2O2 (0.12 M) in 5 mL methanol (CH3OH) and 1 mmol of BA (0.2 M) at room temperature (RT). The reaction was monitored for 1 h to obtain the optimized parameter. Under this condition the BA to benzaldehyde conversion was found to be 51 % with 93 % selectivity. From our previous studies it was evident that the reaction is solvent dependent [11,12,14]. So, to see the impact of solvent, the reaction was monitored in other solvents like CH3CN (acetonitrile), H2O (deionised water), DMF (dimethyl formamide), DCM (dichloromethane). The % conversion and % selectivity obtained in different solvents are shown graphically in Fig. 2a. The CH3CN was found to be the most suitable solvent giving highest conversion of 64 % and selectivity of 93 %. Although in CH3CN the selectivity was high, but the conversion was not comparable to the other reported results [58,59]. For example, Mistri et al. reported for highly selective (100 %) oxidation of BA in CH3CN using Cu loaded LaFeO3 perovskite with 98 % conversion [60]. Similar oxidation reaction catalysed by Fe(II) complexes was also found proceed with 88 % conversion and 100 % selectivity in CH3CN [61]. Silva and Martins et al. in a recent review article reported that the Cu(II) complexes shows good activity for BA oxidation in presence of H2O2 in CH3CN [62]. It was stated that the CH3CN being of medium polarity gets easily miscible with water and supports various organic solvents and organic compound. One of the important characteristics of CH3CN is that it is inert under oxidation condition and do not hamper the catalytic cycle [62]. Therefore, to further improve the reaction in CH3CN the amount of oxidant, H2O2 was varied from lower to higher concentration. It was observed that the decrease in H2O2 concentration leads to the decrease in productivity of the reaction while increasing the oxidant amount upto 100 µL (0.25 M in 5 mL CH3CN) resulted in significant improvement in the % conversion upto 79 % with 95 % selectivity, Fig. 2b. Increase in H2O2 amount above 110 µL decreased the % selectivity. The decrease in selectivity was due to over oxidation of benzaldehyde to benzoic acid. Hence, 100 µL of H2O2 was considered as the optimum oxidant amount. The reaction was also found to be dependent on the amount of catalyst. To see the influence of catalyst amount, the reaction was carried out with the different amounts of catalyst, and it was found that the conversion increased to 82 % with 5 mg (0.0017 M) of the catalyst Fig. 2c. The impact of time was screened by performing the reaction at a different time interval. The reaction was monitored for 2.5 h and a high conversion of 95 % was found on running the reaction for 2 h, Fig. 2d. Since the reaction took place nicely at room temperature therefore no temperature effect monitoring was carried out. After the reaction with CuPhenAc, the reaction was also carried out with CuPhenCl complex. Under the optimized conditions, the results were slightly improved to 96 % conversion. This indicated that the change in the axially co-ordinated labile ligand like CH3COO- or Cl- did not influence the reaction kinetics to a greater extent. 4.2 Benzyl alcohol oxidation with dinuclear copper (II) complexes After successful oxidation of BA to benzaldehyde with the mono-nuclear copper complexes, the reaction was performed with two synthesized dinuclear complexes. Without going for any optimized condition, the BA oxidation was first tested with CuPhenMAc complex. However, under the optimized condition for mononuclear complexes, the dinuclear complexes did not show any significant result; only 5 % conversion was observed. Hence, the reaction conditions were again standardized considering the dinuclear CuPhenMAc complex. The reaction did not proceed at room temperature (RT) with the binuclear complexes. Therefore, considering 2 mg (0.0005 M) of the catalyst 100 µL (0.25 M) H2O2, 5 mL CH3CN as a solvent the reaction was performed at 40 °C for 2 h. Under this condition, the CuPhenMAc resulted in 58 % conversion with 63.5 % selectivity of benzaldehyde. On increasing the temperature upto 70 °C, both the conversion and selectivity improved to 75 % and 65 %, respectively, Fig. 3a. The increase in temperature upto 80 °C leads to the slight over oxidation of the product hampering the selectivity of the reaction. Therefore, 70 °C was recorded to be the suitable temperature for selective oxidation of BA using the dinuclear CuPhenMAc complex. After getting the optimized temperature, the reaction was performed in different solvents, and the results are depicted in Fig. 3b. Interestingly, the results were found to be good in the protic solvents like ethanol (C2H5OH), H2O and CH3OH than in comparison to other solvents. The best result was found with C2H5OH with 78 % selectivity. The variation of oxidant also predicted that 80 µL of H2O2 (0.2 M) was good enough for getting a high conversion of 80 % BA to benzaldehydes in 2 h, Fig. 3c. On varying the catalyst amount it was found that 3 mg of the complex (0.00073 M in 5 mL C2H5OH) was sufficient to provide 83 % conversion, 70 % selectivity. Under this optimize condition the CuPhenIm complex did not give the same results implying the impact of ligand environment on the catalytic activity. As the temperature was concerned with this complex it required low temperature in comparison to the CuPhenMAc and the reaction occurred at 50 °C. On optimizing the solvent condition methanol (CH3OH) was found to be best in this case. The catalyst amount was almost same as above, but required different amount of H2O2 and it was found to be 70 µL as the optimum. 4.3 Benzyl alcohol oxidation with CuO nanocatalyst The same BA oxidation reaction was again performed with CuO nanocatalyst derived from CuPhenIm complex. As the material was different from the previous four complexes so the reaction condition was newly optimized. Using this nanocatalyst, the reaction proceeded with good conversion and selectivity. However, on optimization of the parameter it was found that with CuO-NPs it required slightly higher temperature i.e. 80 °C. The H2O2 itself may get decompose at higher temperature and can catalysed the reaction. Therefore, in order to understand the role of temperature and catalyst, the reaction was again performed only with H2O2 at different temperature. But the results depicted in graph (Fig. S16) clearly indicated that H2O2 alone at higher temperature could not bring sufficient conversion of BA. However, in presence of CuO nanocatalyst, the % conversion was found to be significantly high implying the role of both the nanocatalyst and temeperature. With the CuO catalyst, the conversion and selectivity were preferentially higher in CH3CN solvent in presence of 60 µL of H2O2 (0.15 M). The reaction required 10 mg of catalyst amount and completed within 2 h with 84 % conversion and 93 % selectivity. The optimized graphs are provided in Fig. 4. ( Table 2). 4.4 Catechol oxidation by copper (II) complexes As similar type of Cu complexes was earlier studied for the catechol oxidation, so our synthesized mononuclear, dinuclear and the nanocatalyst was also subjected for catechol oxidation reaction. At first catalytic oxidation of catechol was performed using all the synthesized Cu complex in CH3CN with H2O2 as oxidant. Both the mononuclear complexes did not show any activity towards catechol oxidation reaction. The reactivity of the nanocatalyst was also not very significant. It only resulted in ~30 % of catechol oxidation product. Fortunately, the dinuclear complexes showed some good results in catechol oxidation. The catechol oxidation was then studied considering the 1 mmol (0.2 M) of catechol as a test substrate using 1 mg (0.00017 M) of CuPhenIm complex with 20 µL H2O2 (0.05 M) at room temperature in presence of 5 mL methanol (CH3OH) solvent for 20 min. Under this condition, the catechol conversion to o-benzoquinone was found to be good and highly selective upto 98 %. The catechol oxidation reaction was thereafter optimized under different reaction parameters and is shown graphically in Fig. 5. The reaction took place very well with both the complexes at RT, giving 85–88 % conversion and 100 % selectivity to benzoquinone. The optimized graph predicted that the reaction proceeded well in CH3OH with both the complexes (CuPhenMAc, CuPhenIm). It required optimized oxidant amount of 60 µL of H2O2 (0.15 M) and catalyst amount of 3 mg (0.0005 M). The progress of the reaction was monitored using UV–vis spectroscopy, the observed peak at ~277 nm was for catechol and that at ~390 nm was for the ortho-benzoquinone, Fig. S17a. The absence of any other peak clearly indicated for the selective conversion of catechol to quinone, [63,64]. The rate constant of the reaction was evaluated by initial rate-determining method by plotting ln (A0 /At) versus time (t), where Ao = Initial concentration of catechol, At = concentration left after time, t. To determine kinetic parameters, we measured the UV of each solution after a time interval of 10 min. It is pertinent to mention herein that before every record the reaction mixture (i.e. the reaction mixture of CuPhenIm + catechol + H2O2 in CH3OH) was subjected to a work-up method to separate the catalyst from solution with ethyl acetate and water. The plot of ln (A0 /At) vs time gave the slope value and from this the rate constant was found to be k = 0.0178 min−1 by using 0.1 mM of substrate, Fig. S17b. Further to study the kinetics, the oxidation reaction rate and the substrate concentrations were fitted to the Michaelis–Menten equation, Vo = Vmax [S]/([S]+KM), to determine KM. The Michaelis–Menten kinetic parameters i.e. the maximum rate Vmax, the Michaelis constant KM and the catalytic rate kcat were determined by Lineweaver-Burk plot. To determine the kinetic parameters, we took 0.1 mg mL−1 of catalyst concentration with different concentrations of the substrate prepared in CH3OH. The rate of the reaction versus substrate concentration variation plots are depicted in Fig. 6a. From the linear fitted Lineweaver-Burk plot shown in Fig. 6b, the parameters were calculated as Vmax = 5.55 × 10−5 Mmin−1, KM = 2.7 × 10−6 M and catalytic constant kcat = 270 h−1 for CuPhenMAc complex. For CuPhenIm, it was found as Vmax = 8.26 × 10−5 Mmin−1, KM = 3.6 × 10−6 M and kcat= 401.8 h−1. 4.5 Mechanistic study of BA oxidation As the mono nuclear complexes showed good result in BA oxidation. So, the mechanistic aspect of the reaction was studied considering one of the mono nuclear complexes i.e CuPhenCl. The mechanism of the reaction was believed to proceed as per the plausible mechanism shown in Scheme 2. At the first step the Cl- ion was supposed to get replaced by the solvent CH3CN to form [Cu(CH3CN)(Phen)2]2+ complex. After the formation of this [Cu(Phen)2CH3CN]2+ complex, it became easy for the H2O2 to form the copper hydroperoxo complex, [Cu(OOH)(Phen)2]+. The active [Cu(OOH)(Phen)2]+ species then facilitated the selective oxidation BA to benzaldehydes as shown in Scheme 2. The interaction of CH3CN and its complexation was evident from the UV–vis studies recorded at higher concentration (0.1 M) of the complex. The CuPhenCl complex in CH3CN exhibited two prominent broad signals at ~440 nm and ~670 nm, Fig. 7a [65]. On increasing the concentration of CH3CN, the peak at ~440 nm grow sharper with increase in absorbance value, while the absorbance value of the peak at higher wavelength slightly got lowered. These two signals were not observed on the UV–vis spectrum of the same complex recorded in water or other protic solvent like CH3OH and C2H5OH. Time-dependent density-functional theory (TD-DFT) calculations were performed to understand the nature of the observed electronic transitions, Fig. 7b. The TD-DFT spectra predicted that the peak at ~440 originated from HOMO-6 to LUMO transition, Fig. 7c. While that at higher wavelength appeared due to HOMO-2 to LUMO transition. The HOMO-6 and HOMO-2 were mostly located at the Phen-ligand while the LUMO was centred at Cu-CH3CN unit. This implied that to these transitions there was a contribution from ligand to metal charge transfer as well as from intra-ligand transition i.e. from Phen to CH3CN. The weak transition that was found at ~501 nm in the TD-spectra was not observed under our experimental conditions. However, resemblance of the experimentally observed two peaks, especially that at ~440 nm with that predicted from the theoretical calculations (in gas phase) clearly provided a strong evidence for the formation of [Cu(CH3CN)(Phen)2]2+ complex during the part of the reaction. The formation [Cu(OOH)(Phen)2]+ species was confirmed by the FTIR and Raman analysis recorded after addition of H2O2. The FTIR and Raman spectra before and after addition of H2O2 are shown in Fig. 7d and Fig. 7e, respectively. The appearance of ν(O-O) vibration at ~860.3 cm−1 in FTIR and ~861.8 cm−1 in Raman spectra after addition of H2O2 clearly indicated the formation of mononuclear hydroperoxo Cu(II) complex, [Cu(OOH)(Phen)2]+ [66,67]. This observation was similar to the theoretically calculated FTIR signals showing the Cu-O-O-H vibrational band at ~857.5 cm−1, Fig. 7f. The exchangeable property of chloro or the acetate ligand with the solvent i.e. CH3CN was also clearly evident from the shifting of the redox potential value in different solvent for both the complexes as shown in Fig. 8a,b. Leandri et al. obtained similar observation while CH3CN was bound with Cu-complex by a exchangeable ion site [68]. The interaction of oxidant and the reactant was further monitored through the cyclic voltametric study. In presence of the oxidant (H2O2) the peaks were observed at +0.15 and −0.30 resulted from the interaction of Cu-centre with the oxidant. In the presence of both oxidant and BA it showed the retention of the initial redox couple (Fig. 8c, red) with slight lowering of the potential values from +0.1 V to +0.08 V Epc, +0.2 V to +0.14 V Epa. The appearance of new irreversible redox couple at +0.29 V and −0.25 V with the sharp increase in the current density signifies for the interaction of oxidant and the substrate with the metal complex, resulting in the oxidation of BA. Similar to CuPhenCl, the CuPhenAc also showed the change in cyclic voltammogram pattern with the appearance of new signal as shown in Fig. 8d (black) confirming the interaction of the substrate. The signals at −0.22 V, −0.65 V was for Cu-O2 - species and Cu-superoxo species as reported by Brinkmeier et al. confirming the interaction of H2O2 with the Cu complex [68]. The change in the redox potential values was also correlated with the change in the energies of HOMO and LUMO orbitals as observed from the calculations performed with [Cu(Phen)2Cl]+ complex. On substituting with CH3CN and H2O2, the HUMO-LUMO energy gaps were found to decrease leading to significant changes in the redox potential values. Thus, the UV–vis analysis and cyclic voltametric study predicted for the lability of Cl- with solvent like CH3CN, H2O, and methanol. As the catalytic reactions were performed using H2O2 as oxidant so there is a possibility that the reaction may be mediated by radicals like superoxide radicals (O2-•) or HO•(hydroxyl radical). While studying the reaction mechanism through CV analysis no redox signals were observed for Cl-/Cl0 or Cl0/Cl+ couple. Hence, the role Cl- or Cl• radical in BA oxidation was not taken in consideration. The most possible radical that can be generated from H2O2 is HO•. Therefore, to understand the possible role of such radicals, the BA oxidation reaction was again tested under the optimized conditions with CuPhenCl complex using the radical scavenging agent TEMPO (2,2,6,6-Tetramethylpiperidin-1-yl)oxyl). However, it was observed that the % selectivity and % conversion of BA oxidation were not hampered by the introduction of such a radical scavenging agent. This implied that the radical did not participate in the reaction mechanism. In the other words, it can be said that radicals were not responsible to bring any conversion of BA to benzaldehyde. The same experiment was also performed with CuO nanocatalyst. However, in presence of TEMPO and with CuO nanocatalyst under the optimized condition, the % conversion of BA oxidation was found to drop from 84 % to 32 % implying the role of radicals. The presence of HO• radical was further confirmed by the coumarin test. It is well mentioned in the literature that coumarin usually does not give fluorescent spectra above 350 nm [69]. However, the •OH radical trapped coumarin i.e., 7-hydroxy coumarin gives a fluorescent band at 455 nm [70]. On performing the coumarin test it was observed that the intensity of the band at 455 nm gradually increased with an increase in reaction time, Fig S18. This implied that in the presence of CuO-nanocatalyst, HO• radicals were generated and participated in the oxidation of BA. Thus, from the above investigation, it was concluded that the BA oxidation with mononuclear Cu(II) complexes or with single site Cu(II) catalyst proceeded without the involvement of free radicals while the same was not observed with CuO nanocatalyst. So, this also brings out a significant difference in the reaction mechanism and thereby also brings the difference in the catalytic activity of single and multiple site catalysts in BA oxidation. 4.6 Mechanistic study of catechol oxidation The mechanism of catechol oxidation was believed to proceed by the steps shown in Scheme 3. The catecholate ion was supposed to bind to the Cu centre with the release of 2 moles of CH3OH via the exchange of catechol with ligand bound to the metal complex. The formation of the ortho-benzoquinone i.e. the oxidised product of catechol was further assisted by the acetate ligand. The oxidant further participated in returning the complex back to its original form as shown in Scheme 3 (inset). DFT calculations were performed to see the geometrical changes and to know the energy changes involved in going from Complex 1(CuPhenMAc)→ Complex 2→ Complex 3→ Complex 1 shown in Scheme 3. The optimized geometries are provided in Fig. S19 and the cartesian co-ordinates of all the species are given in Table S6. In Complex 1(shown in Scheme 3), Cu-O(CH3O) was found to be 1.865 Å and 1.880 Å with two Cu-centre. While in complex 2, after bonded with O-atom of C6H4(OH)(O-) species, the Cu-O bond distance of 1.952 Å was found to be same with both the Cu-centre. On the other hand, H-atoms of OH in both C6H4(OH)(O-) species were weekly bonded with O-atoms of bridged CH3COO group of the Cu complex at a distance of 1.956 Å and 1.957 Å. In the next step, H-atoms of OH in both C6H4(OH)(O-) species came closer to O-atoms of CH3COO in the Cu complex (Complex 3), and maintained an equal distance of 1.474 Å. At the same time, the O-H distance of both C6H4(OH)(O-) species also increased (O-H distance of 1.038 Å) in complex 3 as compared to complex 2 (O-H distance of 0.983 Å). We found from this analysis that H-atoms of OH-atoms in both C6H4(OH)(O-) species came closer to O-atoms of CH3COO in the Cu complex but H-atom was not completely removed from C6H4(OH)(O-) species. Moreover, we have calculated Wiberg bond index values (obtain from NBO analysis) for complex 2 and complex 3 in which H-atoms of OH-atoms in both C6H4(OH)(O-) species interacted with these complexes as given in Table S4. The Wiberg index value for H-atoms of OH in both C6H4(OH)(O-) and O-atoms of CH3COO in Cu complex was equal to 0.035 in complex 2 but this value was found to be 0.182 in complex 3, Table S4. This indicated that H-atoms of OH in both C6H4(OH)(O-) were strongly attracted to O-atoms of CH3COO in the Cu complex. The Wiberg index value for O-atoms in both C6H4(OH)(O-) and Cu-atoms of complex 2 was equal to 0.325 while in complex 3 it was equal to 0.377. This implied that O-atoms in both C6H4(OH)(O-) and Cu-atoms of complex 3 were more strongly attracted than O-atoms in both C6H4(OH)(O-) and Cu-atoms of Cu complex 2. Frequency calculations of all species were further performed and the different modes of vibration frequencies are provided in Table S7. From Table S7, it was observed that all the stationary points were found to have real positive vibrational frequencies, corresponding to stable minima. During frequency calculation, absolute values of thermodynamic parameters such as enthalpy (H) and Gibbs free energies (G) were calculated. These values for all species are given in Table S5. Using Table S5, the Enthalpy change (ΔrH°298) and Gibbs free energy change (ΔrG°298) for 1→2, 2→3 and 3→1 reaction steps (Shown in Scheme 3) were calculated and the values are reported in Table S5. In going from Complex 1 → Complex 2, the values of ΔrH°298 and ΔrG°298 were found to be −36.96 kcal mol−1and −49.94 kcal mol−1, respectively. These values show that this step was exothermic and spontaneous. Similarly, the values of ΔrH°298 and ΔrG°298 for the two steps (Complex 2→ Complex 3 and Complex 3→ Complex 1) were also exothermic and spontaneous but each successive step was slightly less exothermic and spontaneous than the previous step. 4.7 Recyclability and hot-filtration test of the CuO nanocatalyst As the mononuclear and dinuclear complexes behave as homogeneous catalyst, so it was difficult for us to recycle the catalyst. However, the CuO nanocatalyst derived from the metal complex, exhibited some good recyclability property. The catalyst was recyclable upto 8 cycles without any significant loss in the activity. To check the recyclability test, we performed the BA oxidation with the recycle catalyst and its conversion with its respective cycles is shown in Fig. S21a. The hot filtration test was performed during the course of reaction to check the true heterogeneity of the material. The test was carried out by removing the catalyst after 1 h of reaction by filtration and further performing the reaction with the remaining filtrate. No any improvement in the % conversion was observed and remained constant upto 2 h. The obtained result of this test indicated that the reaction did not convert in the absence of CuO nanocatalyst implying the true heterogeneous nature of the reaction, (Fig. S21b). 5 Conclusion In conclusion it can be said that Cu(II) systems with different active sites were studied for BA and catechol oxidation. Our studies predicted that the depending on the nature of the Cu-phenanthroline complex the reactivity of the complexes in catalytic oxidation was found to be different. The comparative study predicted that the mono-nuclear Cu(II) complexes with single metal active site exhibited superior activity in BA oxidation while the bridge dinuclear complexes dominated the catechol oxidation. Spectroscopic and theoretical evidences provided a convincing idea about the reaction mechanism while the kinetic studies gave a proper knowledge about the rate of the reaction condition. The CuO nanocatalyst was found to stand more active in terms of recyclability and reusability. But its activity was counterpoised by the single site mononuclear Cu(II) complex. coredata.dc:description: Cu(II) catalysts both in homogeneous and heterogeneous form were synthesized to bring the distinction between the single and multiple site catalysis. The single site mononuclear complexes with axial occupancy of Cl- and CH3COO- ligand and the acetate, imidazolate bridged dinuclear Cu(II) complexes were tested for selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol and catechol oxidation. The reactivity of the complexes was compared with the multiple site copper oxide (CuO) nanocatalyst derived from the metal complex precursor. The single site Cu(II) catalyst showed much superior activity in the selective oxidation of BA compared to the dinuclear and the CuO-nanocatalyst. The oxidation of catechol to o-benzoquinone was however found to be catalyzed more preferably by the di-nuclear systems. The high lability of Cl- and -OOCH3 groups in the mononuclear complexes allowed the incoming oxidant, substrate as well as the solvent (acetonitrile, CH3CN) molecules to interact with the active Cu-centre and thereby favoured the benzyl alcohol oxidation. Both the experimental and theoretical studies provided a conclusive idea about the reaction mechanism of benzyl alcohol and catechol oxidation. UV–vis, cyclic voltammetric study and density functional theory (DFT) calculations provided the strong evidence for the formation of Cu-CH3CN complex during benzyl alcohol oxidation. FTIR and Raman study substantiated by the theoretical calculations indicated for the formation of Cu- hydroperoxo species during the catalytic studies. The kinetics study revealed for the 1st order kinetic for the catechol oxidation and the DFT study predicted for the exothermic nature of the catechol oxidation process.
coredata.dc:title: Single and multiple site Cu(II) catalysts for benzyl alcohol and catechol oxidation reactions
